docs.snippet: Google expands a rewards program that is designed to compensate hackers who find security flaws in the company's products....
docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year I wrote a story about the enigmatic world of cybersecurity, where "white hat" hackers work with corporations to find flaws in computer systems, in the hope of fending off "black hat" hackers who try to take advantage of these vulnerabilities.

headline.main: Google Extends Security Reward Program

docs.abstract: Google expands a rewards program that is designed to compensate hackers who find security flaws in the company's products.

docs.snippet: A new keyboard interface designed for the Google Android phone looks confusing, but its inventors say it is easy to use and could replace keyboards now on mobile phones....
docs.lead_paragraph: Some people are born with a knack for typing quickly on a mobile phone, clacking away at a virtual or physical keyboard as if it were attached to a desktop computer. But if you weren't, there may be help, from 3qubits, a mobile phone software company started by two Ph.D. mathematics student at Cambridge University in England. Their solution to tiny mobile keyboards is  a new virtual keyboard they call 8Pen, expected to be introduced on Tuesday.

headline.main: Help for Slow Mobile Phone Typists

docs.abstract: A new keyboard interface designed for the Google Android phone looks confusing, but its inventors say it is easy to use and could replace keyboards now on mobile phones.

docs.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission announced Wednesday that it would cease its inquiry into Google's collection of consumer data transmitted over wireless networks by its Street View cars.      In a letter issued Wednesday morning, David C. Vladek, the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission announced Wednesday that it would cease its inquiry into Google's collection of consumer data transmitted over wireless networks by its Street View cars. In a letter issued Wednesday morning, David C. Vladek, the director of the bureau of consumer protection, cited the steps the company had taken in response to concerns that it had collected unencrypted ''payload data,'' including the appointment of a director of privacy for engineering and product management, additional staff training on privacy issues and the incorporation of a new privacy review process for new initiatives.

headline.main: Local Push By Google

docs.abstract: Bits blog; Google introduces Place Search feature to find local businesses and Boost, a new type of advertisement for those businesses; company aims to make it easier for small businesses to place ads that appear in local searches; photo (M)

docs.snippet: A couple of simple fixes for the things that Microsoft Windows Phone 7 software didn't quite get to....
docs.lead_paragraph: As you probably know from my  New York Times review, I'm genuinely excited about Windows Phone 7. True, nobody's exactly clamoring for yet another app-phone software platform-can Microsoft really offer anything that's sorely lacking by the iPhone or Android phones?-but the design is successful and completely different from what's come before. And the competition will keep Apple and Google on their toes.

docs.snippet: This week's topics include Claire Cain Miller on Google, StreetView and privacy and managing your digital footprint....
docs.lead_paragraph: Although the Federal Trade Commission last week dropped its investigation of personal data inadvertently collected by Google's StreetView cars, state authorities and officials in European and other countries are still looking into privacy issues related to the service. On this week's Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a New York Times technology reporter who covers Google, about the latest developments. Ms. Miller says that Google has taken new steps aimed at protecting privacy, which satisfied the F.T.C., but consumer groups and privacy advocates are dismayed about the agency's decision. Google recently revealed that in addition to location photos, its StreetView cars gathered passwords and e-mail from unencrypted Wi-Fi networks.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Online Privacy

docs.abstract: This week's topics include Claire Cain Miller on Google, StreetView and privacy and managing your digital footprint.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Google and VivaKi, a digital agency that is part of the Publicis Groupe, will announce a two-year renewal of their 2008 partnership that will incorporate a new platform for buying video and mobile display ads in the United States and Europe. The platform, an extension of the VivaKi Nerve Center trading desk, or the Audience on Demand product, would allow companies to bid on mobile and video display advertising space in real time on ad exchanges, including Google's DoubleClick exchange.

docs.snippet: Joshua Roberts/Bloomberg NewsThe Securities and Exchange Commission headquarters.Has the Securities and Exchange Commission bungled its disclosure rules?     That's the question being whispered around Wall Street trading floors after a series of c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Joshua Roberts/Bloomberg NewsThe Securities and Exchange Commission headquarters.Has the Securities and Exchange Commission bungled its disclosure rules? That's the question being whispered around Wall Street trading floors after a series of company disclosures in recent weeks from the likes of Microsoft and Google that appear to have created an awful lot of confusion, potentially giving some savvy investors an edge while potentially putting the rest of us at a disadvantage.

headline.main: A Lack of Transparency In S.E.C. Disclosure Rule

docs.abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin Dealbook column on possible lack of transparency in Securities and Exchange Commission disclosure rules; says issue came to light after Microsoft took advantage of vaguely-written guidelines that allow companies to publish market-moving news like company reports directly on their own Web sites without requiring wider distribution; also notes that Google began publishing its results on its own Web site over summer; holds that Internet has potential to make disclosure far more transparent by allowing companies to reach more people, but rules governing such disclosures are easily misinterpreted or manipulated; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Facebook plans to build its second standalone data center in North Carolina where access to inexpensive power has attracted companies like Google and Apple before....
docs.lead_paragraph: Following in the footsteps of Google, Yahoo and Microsoft, which are building ever-growing networks of data centers, Facebook said Thursday that it will build a new data center in Forest City, N.C. This will be the second data center that Facebook is building from the ground up. Its first center in Prineville, Ore., is under construction and is expected to open next year. Facebook also leases data center space -- and in some cases entire data centers -- in several other locations, including Santa Clara, Calif.

headline.main: Facebook Chooses North Carolina for New Data Center

docs.abstract: Facebook plans to build its second standalone data center in North Carolina where access to inexpensive power has attracted companies like Google and Apple before.

docs.snippet: Ab Ex now has its own app. In conjunction with its ''Abstract Expressionist New York'' exhibition, the grand tour through the Museum of Modern Art's holdings of (mostly) New York School masterpieces, the museum has just released its first applicat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ab Ex now has its own app. In conjunction with its ''Abstract Expressionist New York'' exhibition, the grand tour through the Museum of Modern Art's holdings of (mostly) New York School masterpieces, the museum has just released its first application for the Apple iPad, which is rapidly becoming a museum-going staple. The app, which is free at Apple's store, includes images of 60 of the paintings, drawings and sculptures in the show, which can be navigated chronologically or by artist, from William Baziotes to Jack Tworkov. It includes a customized Google map that allows users to pinch and scroll around Manhattan and parts of Long Island for the sites where Abstract Expressionism was born and nurtured, from Barnett Newman's East 19th Street Studio to the Cedar Tavern. And it also includes 20 short videos featuring curators and other experts, along with a dictionary for the truly dedicated art patron of Ab Ex technical terms like emulsion and turpentine burn.

headline.main: MoMA Hops On the iPad App Bandwagon

docs.abstract: Museum of Modern Art launches first Apple iPad application in connection with major MoMA exhibition, Abstract Expressionist New York (S)

docs.snippet: Google Chrome is providing free wireless Internet access on three airlines - AirTran, Delta and Virgin America - from Nov. 20 through Jan. 2 as part of a promotion for the  browser.     The carriers' passengers will be able to browse the Web via G...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google Chrome is providing free wireless Internet access on three airlines - AirTran, Delta and Virgin America - from Nov. 20 through Jan. 2 as part of a promotion for the browser. The carriers' passengers will be able to browse the Web via Gogo Inflight Internet, which allows users to go online midflight with Wi-Fi-enabled devices like laptops, iPads and smartphones. Passengers will be able to use any browser they wish while surfing the Web but will be invited to download Google Chrome upon landing.

headline.main: Web Browser Offering Free Airborne Wi-Fi

docs.snippet: Will La Grande Dame's New Web Site Boost Sales?...
docs.lead_paragraph: In July, She Owns It introduced readers to La Grande Dame, an online retailer of high-end, plus-size designer clothing for women. The post chronicled the start-up's experiences with Google AdWords and search engine optimization and its eventual decision to cut Google's pay-per-click advertising product from its marketing mix. Several readers commented that La Grande Dame's Web site contributed to its S.E.O. challenges and urged an overhaul to address that issue and improve the site's appearance and functionality. La Grande Dame took the comments -- and similar ones from its customers -- to heart, and unveiled its new site last week. "Our ultimate goal was to improve the user experience and make it easier for shoppers to find what they want," said Catherine Wood Hill, La Grande Dame's chief executive.

headline.main: A Web Retailer Starts Over

docs.abstract: Will La Grande Dame's New Web Site Boost Sales?

docs.snippet: Google failed in China because it did not understand the Chinese Internet market, not because the playing field was unfairly tilted against it, said Robin Li, the chief executive of Baidu, the Chinese search engine that dominates in China.      Mr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google failed in China because it did not understand the Chinese Internet market, not because the playing field was unfairly tilted against it, said Robin Li, the chief executive of Baidu, the Chinese search engine that dominates in China. Mr. Li, speaking at the Web 2.0 conference in San Francisco Monday, was making his first public comments at an American industry conference. He spoke shortly after Eric E. Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, had taken the same stage.

headline.main: Chinese View Of Google's Issues

docs.abstract: Bits blog on Chinese search engine Baidu chief executive Robin Li, who says Google failed in China because it did not understand Chinese Internet market, not because playing field was unfairly tilted against it; photo (S)

docs.snippet: The Moment asked Olivia Palermo, whose boutique is already the second most followed, about her involvement with the much ballyhooed new site....
docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, Google unveiled its e-commerce fashion venture, Boutiques.com, at the heart of which are online stores curated by celebrities and tastemakers. The Moment asked Olivia Palermo, whose boutique is already the second most followed, about her involvement with the much ballyhooed new site. "The process was a ton of fun," Palermo said, "but I actually spent hours playing with it. It's quite addictive!" No stranger to online shopping, Palermo has mostly been browsing on net-a-porter.com and matchesfashion.com for Giambattista Valli, Christopher Kane and the French label Maje to feature in her boutique, her goal being to make scouring the racks easy and accessible for shoppers with similar taste. "Whether it's a Marchesa gown straight off the runway or a basic Topshop piece, everything is at your fingertips," she says. She appreciates Google's complex algorithms, which show browsers alternative items should the ones they want be unavailable or too pricey. The downside? "It's accessible and free - until you start buying all the items you find."

headline.main: Now Curating | Olivia Palermo for Boutiques.com

docs.abstract: The Moment asked Olivia Palermo, whose boutique is already the second most followed, about her involvement with the much ballyhooed new site.

docs.snippet: SHOPPING online in late July, Clarabelle Rodriguez typed the name of her favorite eyeglass brand into Google's search bar.     In moments, she found the perfect frames -- made by a French company called Lafont -- on a Web site that looked snazzy a...
docs.lead_paragraph: SHOPPING online in late July, Clarabelle Rodriguez typed the name of her favorite eyeglass brand into Google's search bar. In moments, she found the perfect frames -- made by a French company called Lafont -- on a Web site that looked snazzy and stood at the top of the search results. Not the tippy-top, where the paid ads are found, but under those, on Google's version of the gold-medal podium, where the most relevant and popular site is displayed.

headline.main: A Bully Finds a Pulpit on the Web

docs.snippet: Google updated its Google Earth software, introducing real-life images of streets from around the world and adding 80 million virtual trees....
docs.lead_paragraph: In late September, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, explained at a press event that he wanted Google to be "the third half of your brain." Mr. Brin wasn't just referring to the company's search products when he made that somewhat eerie proclamation. He was also alluding to a number of  products that should be expected in the coming years.

headline.main: Google Earth Pushes Boundaries Between Real and Virtual

docs.abstract: Google updated its Google Earth software, introducing real-life images of streets from around the world and adding 80 million virtual trees.

docs.snippet: The pace at a big company is far slower than at a start-up, a difference that matters to the entrepreneurial spirit....
docs.lead_paragraph: The pace at a big company is far slower than at a start-up, a difference that matters to the entrepreneurial spirit.

headline.seo: Now a Giant, Google Works to Retain Nimble Minds
headline.main: Google Grows, and Works to Retain Nimble Minds
headline.print_headline: Google Grows, So Some Talent Takes Its Leave

docs.snippet: Buying an online coupon company could help Google dominate local advertising, but the $6 billion deal worries investors because of its price....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google's $6 billion bid for Groupon, an online coupon start-up, is an aggressive move by the company to dominate local online advertising and help with its long-sought move into social networking.

headline.main: Google Gambit for Groupon Raises Concern

docs.abstract: Buying an online coupon company could help Google dominate local advertising, but the $6 billion deal worries investors because of its price.

byline.original: By EVELYN M. RUSLI and JENNA WORTHAM

docs.snippet: Dan W. Reicher, an energy expert who is leaving Google for Stanford, says that policy mechanisms will be critical to making progress on a shift to renewables....
docs.lead_paragraph: Dan W. Reicher, a former assistant secretary of energy, has left Google, where he spent the last four years as director of climate change and energy initiatives. In that post he helped develop Google's goal of seeking to make renewable energy less expensive than coal, abbreviated as RE<C.

headline.main: Google Energy Guru Will Head Policy Center at Stanford

docs.abstract: Dan W. Reicher, an energy expert who is leaving Google for Stanford, says that policy mechanisms will be critical to making progress on a shift to renewables.

docs.snippet: Google begins to populate its virtual Earth with trees....
docs.lead_paragraph: Last year, Google filled in the big blue blank spot on its online replica of the Earth with three-dimensional oceans. Whether they'll help inspire people to take care of the real oceans remains unclear, but it can't hurt. Now the company, in the latest iteration of Google Earth, is filling in some of the vast green blotches with three-dimensional trees.

headline.main: First Seas, Now Trees, Added to Google's Earth

docs.abstract: Google begins to populate its virtual Earth with trees.

docs.snippet: A deal for $5 billion to $6 billion could be struck as soon as this week and would be Google's largest acquisition....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google is near a deal to acquire Groupon, the pioneering online discounter, for as much as $6 billion, people with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook on Monday.

headline.main: Google Is Said to Be Poised to Buy Groupon

docs.abstract: A deal for $5 billion to $6 billion could be struck as soon as this week and would be Google's largest acquisition.

byline.original: By EVELYN M. RUSLI and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

docs.snippet: Google is near a deal to acquire Groupon, the pioneering online discounter, for as much as $6 billion, people with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook on Monday.     A deal, in the $5 billion to $6 billion range, could be struck as soon a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google is near a deal to acquire Groupon, the pioneering online discounter, for as much as $6 billion, people with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook on Monday. A deal, in the $5 billion to $6 billion range, could be struck as soon as this week, these people said, cautioning that the talks still could fall apart.

headline.main: Google Is Said to Be Close to Buying Groupon, a Site for Daily Deals

docs.abstract: Google is said to be near deal to buy online discounter Groupon for as much as $6 billion; it would be largest acquisition ever for Google and would give Google advantage in local business advertising online (M)

byline.original: By EVELYN M. RUSLI and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER
